awd_titl_txt: Collaborative Research: AccessCSforAll: Including Students with Disabilities in High School Computer Science
awd_abstract_narration:
The University of Washington, in collaboration with the University of Nevada Las Vegas, proposes AccessCSforAll, a project to develop strategies, tools, and curricula needed to bring an accessible version of Advanced Placement (AP) Computer Science Principles (CSP) to students, including those with disabilities. Approximately 7.5 million K-12 students are identified as having a disability under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) or Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. These students should have access to quality computer science education, but there are often significant barriers, including inaccessible tools (for example, programming languages, integrated development environments not accessible to screen readers), or curricula that include exclusively visual program output. Civil rights legislation requires that curriculum be offered in a format that is accessible to students with disabilities.

AccessCSforAll will create a researcher practitioner partnership (RPP) that includes practitioners at schools that serve students who are deaf, blind, or learning disabled, as well as schools that serve mainstream students. Building on previous work with more than 30 CS10K projects, AccessforAll will provide professional development for CS teachers that includes strategies for supporting students with disabilities.   It will partner with The College Board to ensure that they are ready to properly evaluate students with disabilities, and it will partner with developers of accessible tools and curricula. The project will develop and maintain resources for computer science teachers to help them better include students with disabilities in their classes, and to showcase solutions for universal design in tools, curriculum, and pedagogy that appeal both to general education students as well as students with disabilities. The project will build a community that is focused on accessible K-12 computer science education.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering
org_div_long_name: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: BOARD OF REGENTS OF NEVADA SYSTEM OF HIGHER EDUCATION

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: Computer Science for All (CS for All)
REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
AccessCSforAll funded by the National Science Foundation as part of the Computing Education for the 21st Century program of the Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering (grants #CNS-1738252 and #CNS-1738259) directly addressed students with disabilities. Approximately 7.5 million K-12 students are identified as having a disability under the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) or Section 504 of the Rehabilitation Act. These students should have access to quality computer science education, but there are often significant barriers, including inaccessible tools (for example, programming languages, integrated development environments not accessible to screen readers), or curricula that include exclusively visual program output. Civil rights legislation requires that curriculum be offered in a format that is accessible to students with disabilities. 

AccessCSforAll had one principal goal which was to increase the successful participation of students with disabilities in high school computing courses, particularly AP CSP. To achieve this goal AccessCSforAll focused on three project objectives:

  • First, to build the capacity of teachers who serve students with disabilities to teach AP CSP through professional development training and individualized real-time support.
  • Second, to create and have the College Board certify an accessible version of AP CSP and foster a community of engaged users.
  • Third, to expand our efforts in being a national resource for teachers, teacher trainers, administrators, and educational tool developers for accessible K-12 computer science education.

Activities to meet these objectives were led by Professor Richard Ladner and Dr. Sheryl Burgstahler at the University of Washington and Professor Andreas Stefik at the University of Nevada, Las Vegas. This work built upon their prior work as well as the work of experienced partners.

 

Activities to Reach Objective 1: Capacity Building for Teachers

The first objective of this project was to build the capacity of teachers who serve students with disabilities to teach AP CSP through professional development training and individualized real-time support. To meet this objective, we developed the AccessCSforAll Research Practitioner Partnership (RPP) and provided three professional development (PD) workshops for each of teachers of blind and visually impaired students, deaf students, and neurodiverse students. In addition to the in-person PDs, teachers in the PDs met remotely at least three times per year to review and evaluate their progress. All participants became part of the AccessCSforAll community of practice and were encouraged to use the real-time support offered by AccessCSforAll.

 

Activities to Reach Objective 2: Creation of Accessible Version of AP CSP

The second objective of this project was to create an accessible version of AP CSP and foster a community of engaged users. For AP CSP to be accessible to all, both the curriculum and tools must be accessible. To that end we developed Quorum based tools and curricula to be used in an accessible version of AP CSP. We partnered with Code.org, which already has a certified curriculum, in order to complete certification of our CSP curriculum with the College Board.  

 

Activities to Reach Objective 3: Expand Efforts to be a National Resource

The third objective of this project was to expand our efforts in being a national resource for teachers, teacher trainers, administrators, and educational tool developers for accessible K-12 computer science education. For this objective, we built upon activities from our previous grant that supported development partners, online resources, community of practice, and real-time support for teachers.

 

Broader Impacts from AccessCSforAll

The main goal of the Computer Science for All initiative is to scale up past efforts to make computer science classes available to all students in the United States. This means reaching more students and more kinds of students, that is, to broaden participation numerically and equitably. Scaling up means including the approximately 15% of high school students who have a disability. AccessCSforAll represented one of the first comprehensive steps to provide that scaling up to include these students. The project developed tools and curricula that will enable more students with disabilities to take and succeed in high school computer science courses. It provided professional development to enable teachers to create computer science courses at schools for students with disabilities and at mainstream schools.  

 


Last Modified: 12/02/2022
Modified by: Andreas M Stefik
